snippet: The misconduct of the financial industry no longer surprises most Americans, and trust in big business overall is declining. We should be alarmed.
abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column says that the Libor scandal is surprising in its familiarity, as Americans are no longer shocked by bad behavior from large banks, and that the tepid public reaction is an indicator that trust in big business overall is in decline; holds Americans should be alarmed that corporate wrongdoing has come to be seen as the norm, insisting that capitalism cannot function without an element of trust in its institutions.
lead_paragraph: The misconduct of the financial industry no longer surprises most Americans, and trust in big business overall is declining. We should be alarmed.

headline.seo: The Spreading Scourge of Corporate Corruption
headline.main: The Spreading Scourge of Corporate Corruption
headline.print_headline: The Spreading Scourge Of Corporate Corruption
